title: Where is Namibia as Scarlett Moffatt meets the Himba tribe in TV show
text:
British Tribe Next Door airs tonight (Picture: Channel 4)

Scarlett Moffatt and her family return to our TV screens tonight, but this time not in Gogglebox, on their new Channel 4 show The British Tribe Next Door.

In the controversial new show, which Scarlett has had to defend following backlash against the show’s concept, the former Queen of the I’m A Celebrity jungle and her family relocated with an exact replica of their home to Namibia.

There, in the middle of a Namibian tribal village, Scarlett and her family lived alongside the local Himba tribe, seeing their two very different livelihoods contrasted in real time.

Where is Namibia, where The British Tribe Next Door is set?

For the show, the Moffatts relocated from County Durham to Namibia, with their semi-detached house (or at least, a replica of) in tow.

The four part series was filmed in the Republic of Namibia, which is located in southern Africa.

Namibia, which is one of the world’s least densely populated countries due to the Namib Desert which stretches along much of the country, borders the Atlantic Ocean to its west and shares land borders with Zambia, Angola, South Africa and Botswana.

Who are the Himba tribe?

Scarlett and her family lived with the nomadic Himba tribe for a month.

The Himba tribe are the indigenous people of Namibia and their population of roughly 50,000 people live largely in the northern part of the country.

Himba tribe member Muvii and Scarlett’s dad Mark. (Picture: David Bloomer/Channel 4)

The Himba people speak a language called OtjiHimba and a predominantly livestock farmers, counting their personal wealth by the number of cattle they own.

Successful in maintaining their culture and traditional life despite the increasing modernity of Namibia as a country, The Himba are considered the last (semi-) nomadic people of Namibia.

On the advice of anthropologists, the house which was built in Namibia for the show was completely removed after filming and is currently being reused in South Africa where it was built.

The Moffatt family left no trace after leaving the Himba Tribe’s village. (Picture: David Bloomer/Channel 4)

Talking on This Morning today, Scarlett revealed that having spent a month living with the Himba tribe but in a replica of their own home, the community were adamant that the Moffatts leave nothing behind when they left.

‘I just assumed, maybe because I’m big-headed, that they would just love our house….instead they found us very isolated,’ Scarlett revealed.

The British Tribe Next Door airs tonight, Tuesday 22 October, at 9.15pm on Channel 4.
